thread.title: Mired in costs, banks miss value in regulatory drive, report says
thread.title_full: Mired in costs, banks miss value in regulatory drive, report says | South China Morning Post

author: DON WEINLAND
title: Mired in costs, banks miss value in regulatory drive, report says
text:
Banks are coming up short-winded and short on cash in the race to comply with global financial regulations, a new report from technology services firm Accenture shows.
It is not just a few banking juggernauts that are paying out heavily to keep up with the steady stream of new rules coming from the United States and from global banking organisations such as the Bank for International Settlements.
About a third of the 131 banks surveyed late last year said they expected to spend more than US$500 million this year alone to get in line with regulations such as Basel III and a recently approved section in the US Dodd-Frank Act, two major challenges in global regulation that fewer than a third of respondents said they were compliant with.
Half the banks said compliance would cost US$200 million this year.
Each respondent had at least US$40 billion in total consolidated assets within a single country. Asia-Pacific represented 25 per cent of the banks in the survey.
Despite the spending, the level of global preparedness for meeting new rules was wanting. About 40 per cent of respondents indicated they were not "well prepared".
As a stark warning to smaller banks coming up against the international effort to normalise financial oversight, 71 per cent said smaller institutions would "fail to keep pace with these new market drivers".
Stricter, further-reaching rules may seem like a one-way street for banks that is set to limit the scope of business and curtail their share of the global financial industry.
After all, 75 per cent of respondents said they foresaw most trading activity in the industry moving outside the formal banking industry to hedge funds and asset management firms.
Some 62 per cent said they would reduce product offerings over the next two years and nearly half said they would home in on their core competencies, indicating that they would not expand businesses into new areas.
But one key takeaway from the Accenture report was that banks struggling to keep abreast of the flood of new rules had lost sight of potential value the process was set to unlock.
"Their plans still appear focused on meeting regulatory demands alone, rather than accounting for the more strategic implications of structural reform," the report said.
The competitive advantages for early movers are vast.
For example, Accenture says banks should think local, not global, based on rules specific to each jurisdiction.
That runs counter to the global banking model before the 2008 financial crisis, where banks attempted to apply a one-size-fits-all framework across different markets.
This article appeared in the South China Morning Post print edition as Banks come up short in following new rules
